titleStmt.title: Memetic binary particle swarm optimization for discrete optimization problems

analytic.title: Memetic binary particle swarm optimization for discrete optimization problems

biblStruct.note: Received 7 December 2013 Received in revised form 8 November 2014 Accepted 3 December 2014

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Optimization Particle swarm optimization Memetic computation Memetic algorithm Binary search space Global and local topologies 2 INS 11300 No. of Pages 27

div.p: In recent decades, many researchers have been interested in algorithms inspired by the 27 observation of natural phenomena to solve optimization problems. Among them, meta-28 heuristic algorithms have been extensively applied in continuous (real) and discrete (bin-29 ary) search spaces. Such algorithms are appropriate for global searches because of their 30 global exploration and local exploitation abilities. In this study, a memetic binary particle 31 swarm optimization (BPSO) scheme is introduced based on hybrid local and global 32 searches in BPSO. The algorithm, binary hybrid topology particle swarm optimization 33 (BHTPSO), is used to solve the optimization problems in the binary search spaces. In addi-34 tion, a variant of the proposed algorithm, binary hybrid topology particle swarm optimiza-35 tion quadratic interpolation (BHTPSO-QI), is proposed to enhance the global searching 36 capability. These algorithms are tested on two set of problems in the binary search space. 37 Several nonlinear high-dimension functions and benchmarks for the 0-1 multidimensional 38 knapsack problem (MKP) are employed to evaluate their performances. Their results are 39 compared with some well-known modified binary PSO and binary gravitational search 40 algorithm (BGSA). The experimental results showed that the proposed methods improve 41 the performance of BPSO in terms of convergence speed and solution accuracy.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Many solutions of optimization problems are expressed as binary representations such as cell formation [15,61], data compression [26,35], feature selection [79,84], unit commitment [14,23], the 0-1 MKP [9,82], and image compression [21,53]. Additionally, problems defined in the real space, may be considered in the binary space. Over the last decades, various population-based meta-heuristic algorithms have been introduced and applied successfully to solve a wide range of the optimization problems in the binary search spaces. Genetic algorithm (GA) [32], simulated annealing (SA) [43], tabu search (TS) [30], artificial immune system (AIS) [25], ant colony optimization (ACO) [24], particle swarm optimization (PSO) [38,39], and gravitational search algorithm (GSA) [69,70] are in the class of such algorithms.

To improve the performance of algorithms in producing better solutions several works in memetic computation (MC) have been carried out. MC is a paradigm that uses the notion of meme(s) as units of information encoded in computational representations for solving problem [20]. It covers a plethora of potentially rich meme-inspired computing methodologies, operational algorithms and frameworks. They have materialized in the form of hybridization between the population-based search (more explorative) and refinement procedures (more exploitative) [46]. Early studies, the adaptive memetic algorithms have presented the significant findings on the local search problems performance [63]. In advanced, Iacca et al. proposed three stages memes based on Ocham's Razor principle for memetic explorations [34]. Meanwhile, Caraffini et al. proposed parallelism on the memes structures for large scale problems and analysis on separability for memetic computing automatic design [12,13]. The parallel structures can be easily implemented within computational devices characterized by hardware limitations [12] while, the separability approach provide lower experience based human influence and a higher machine automatism [13]. Differ from memetic algorithm; hyper-heuristic uses multi-level structures of hybrid metaheuristics. An upper-level acts as primary key player which control several low-level heuristics on the solution space.

These techniques have shown excellent search capabilities in the small or medium sized problems, but the majority of them still encounter serious challenges in large scale problems. These challenges can be summarized as trapping into local optima, slow convergence rate and taking a long time to achieve the results [5,6]. These problems are due to the facts that the complexity and size of a problem usually increases as the number of decision variables, constraints, or objectives increases.

To deal with the problems, this study introduces an improved BPSO scheme, BHTPSO, in the binary search space. The BPSO faces two problems: firstly, it is easily trapped into local optima when solving complex multimodal problems and secondly, all particles are not converged to the best solution [6,60,71]. These problems have impacted the performance of BPSO.

The first problem is because of the poor exploration in PSO and the second is due to the sigmoid function used in BPSO algorithm. Hence, the proposed algorithm performs a global search over the entire search space and increases the ability of jumping from local optima by hybridizing two local and global topologies in PSO. The method applies a suitable function to create new solutions. Additionally, a variant of the proposed algorithm, BHTPSO-QI, is presented to improve the global searching ability.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. A brief review of several binary meta-heuristic algorithms is provided in Section 2. Section 3 describes the proposed algorithms in details. In Section 4, BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI are applied to solve nonlinear high-dimensional benchmark functions, and benchmarks of the 0-1 MKP. In this section, the performance of proposed methods is compared with several modified BPSO algorithms and BGSA algorithms. Finally, conclusions and the future research directions are presented in Section 5.

div.head: Related works
div.p: The binary search space can be considered as a hypercube that a particle or agent may move to nearer and farther corners of the hypercube by flipping various numbers of the bits [69]. Many meta-heuristic algorithms have been proposed for the real and binary search spaces such as GA, PSO and GSA.

PSO and BPSO have simple structure and are easy to implement for solving optimization problems. Hence, they are extensively employed in the problems, however, both algorithms suffer from some disadvantages when solving the complex and high-dimensional multimodal objective functions. PSO may easily get trapped in local optima and show slow convergence rate [6,50]. These drawbacks impact the binary PSO (BPSO) and the algorithm cannot converge well. Hence, a number of variant PSO and BPSO algorithms have been proposed in the literature to overcome the problems. The algorithms have improved the performance of algorithms in different ways using various types of topologies, selecting parameters, combining with other search techniques, and so on.

A local (ring) topological structure PSO (LPSO) [41] and Von Neumann topological structure PSO (VPSO) [40] were proposed by Kennedy and Mendes to enhance the search ability and to avoid trapping into local optima. According to Kennedy [37,41], PSO with a small neighborhood might have a better performance on complex problems, while PSO with a large neighborhood would perform better on simple problems. Dynamic multi-swarm PSO (DMS-PSO) [49] was suggested by Liang and Suganthan where the population is divided into many small swarms, and these swarms are regrouped frequently to exchange the information among the swarms. Mendes et al. [55] presented the fully informed particle swarm (FIPS) algorithm that uses the information of entire neighborhood to guide the particles for finding the best solution. The fitness-distance-ratio-based PSO (FDR-PSO) was introduced by Peram et al. [65]. In the algorithm, each particle moves towards nearby particle with higher fitness value. Liang et al. [50] developed comprehensive learning particle swarm optimization (CLPSO) that each particle learns its behavior from other particles on different dimensions to avoid trapping in the local optima.

An adaptive fuzzy particle swarm optimization (AFPSO) [36] presented to adjust the parameters in PSO based on fuzzy inferences. Some operations from GA were applied into PSO such as selection [1], crossover [17], and mutation [78] to overcome the disadvantages of PSO. Also, several memetic algorithms (MAs) that hybridized PSO with a local search and other techniques were introduced by researchers [52,66,74,80]. Beheshti et al. proposed the median-oriented PSO (MPSO) [8] based on the information from the median particle. Also, they introduced centripetal accelerated PSO (CAPSO) [7] according to Newton's laws of motion to accelerate the learning procedure and convergence rate of optimization problems. Neri et al. [59] suggested compact particle swarm optimization (cPSO) for some application problems characterized by a limited memory. The algorithm applies the search logic typical of PSO plus a probabilistic representation of the swarm behavior. This feature allows the embedded implementation in small and cheap devices. A PSO algorithm based hyper-heuristic algorithm introduced to solve the resource constrained project scheduling problem (RCPSP) [45]. Hyper-heuristics are multi-level/multi-layer algorithms that act as a heuristic scheduler and work as an upper-level algorithm [11]. They control several low-level heuristics and select a suitable low-level heuristic or combination of heuristics to enhance the solution accuracy.

Moreover, several improved BPSO algorithms have been presented to address the drawbacks of BPSO in the binary search space. An angle modulation PSO (AMPSO) was proposed to generate a bit string as a solution to the original high-dimensional problem [64]. In this method, the high dimension bit vector of problem is reduced to a four-dimensional problem defined in the continuous space, with a direct mapping back to the binary space by angle modulation. Sadri and Suen [72] offered a genetic BPSO (GBPSO) model with a non-fix size of the swarm. In the algorithm, two operations of birth and death are introduced to make the population dynamically. Since birth and mortality rates change naturally with time, the model allows oscillations in the size of the population. Hence, the algorithm is more natural simulation of the social behavior of intelligent animals. Khanesar et al. [42] applied a new interpretation for the velocity in BPSO. A modified binary BPSO (MBPSO) was proposed by Lee et al. [48] that adopted concepts of the genotype-phenotype representation and the mutation operator of GA in BPSO. A new BPSO (NBPSO) was presented to overcome the BPSO problems by Rostami-Shahrbabaki et al. [60].

Although the performance of the algorithm is better than BPSO, the NBPSO may trap in the local optimum and encounter prematurely convergence rate. Hence, two different methods were suggested to prevent the stagnation of NBPSO. One of these methods enhances the performance of NBPSO through the concept of guaranteed convergence BPSO (GCBPSO).

Another, improved NBPSO (INBPSO), uses a mutation operator to prevent the stagnation situation. Chen et al. introduced the essential binary PSO (EPSO) [16] for optimization problems in the binary search spaces. In the method, PSO is broken down into its essential components, and alternative interpretations of those components are presented. The previous direction and state of each particle is also taken into account to find good solutions for problems.
In the following section, some of techniques to design a binary algorithm are elucidated and the structure of BPSO, BLPSO, NBPSO and BGSA, are described in details.

div.head: BPSO framework
div.p: The PSO algorithm is a population-based meta-heuristic algorithm that applies two approaches to find the best solution: global exploration and local exploitation. The exploration is the ability of expanding search space whereas the exploitation is the ability of finding the optimum around a good solution. The algorithm is initialized by creating a swarm (population of particles) with random positions. Every particle is shown as a vector, ðX
div.formula: ! i ; V ! i ; P ! best i Þ, in a n-dimensional search space where X ! i
div.p: and V ! i are the position and velocity of the ith particle, respectively, and P ! best i is the personal best position found by the particle as follows:
div.formula: X ! i ¼ x 1 i ; x 2 i ; . . . ; x d i ; . . . ; x n i À Á ; for i ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; N:ð1Þ
V ! i ¼ v 1 i ; v
v d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ wðtÞ Â v d i ðtÞ þ C 1 Â rand 1 Â p d best i ðtÞ À x d i ðtÞ þ C 2 Â rand 2 Â p d g ðtÞ À x d i ðtÞ ;ð5Þ
div.p: where w is inertia weight. C 1 and C 2 are acceleration coefficients; rand 1 and rand 2 are random numbers in the interval [0, 1]. In (5), the second and the third terms are called cognition and social terms, respectively. A larger value of w encourages global exploration (searching new areas); whereas a smaller value provides a local exploitation. The current position, x d i ðtÞ,
div.formula: v d i ðt þ1Þ
div.p: and the next velocity used to update the next position as follows:
div.formula: x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ x d i ðtÞ þ v d i ðt þ 1Þ:ð6Þ
div.p: The PSO algorithm is applied to solve optimization problems in the real search space. A binary version of PSO (BPSO) was proposed by Kennedy and Eberhart [38]. What makes BPSO different from PSO is the particle position that has two possible values, '0' or '1'. The velocity of a particle in BPSO is calculated as the PSO algorithm then, it is transferred into a sigmoid function in the interval [0, 1] as shown in Fig. 1. The particle position is updated as follows:
div.formula: Z. Beheshti Q1 et al. / Information Sciences xxx (2014) xxx-xxx S v d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á ¼ sigmoid v d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á ¼ 1 1 þ e Àv d i ðtþ1Þ ;ð7Þ
if rand < S v d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á then x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ 1 else x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ 0:ð8Þ
v d i ðt þ1Þ
div.p: < v max and v max is equal to 6 according to Fig. 1. In this study, the gbest and lbest models are called BPSO and BLPSO, respectively.

Although BPSO has simple structure, it suffers from some inherent disadvantages [60,71]. A part of drawbacks are directly tied the shortcomings of PSO [5,6] and the others related to its algorithm. PSO has a poor exploration and easily trapped into local optima. Since BPSO employs the velocity equation of PSO, the problems affect the convergence rate in BPSO. Also, the following disadvantages can be appointed to the original BPSO.

The first disadvantage relates to sigmoid function. In the standard PSO, there is no difference between a big value of velocity in the positive and negative direction. A large absolute value of the velocity indicates that the current particle's position is not suitable and a great movement is required to reach the optimum position. Also, a small absolute value of the velocity shows that the current particle's position is close to the optimum position and a small distance requires reaching the optimum position. In contrast, a value in the positive direction causes a bigger probability (probability of 1) for the particle position and makes the probability of zero in the negative direction. In PSO, when the particle velocity tends to zero, it means that particle is in a proper position. In this case, the next position is equal to the current position, while the position in BPSO may be changed to '0' or '1' with probability of 0.5 as shown in Fig. 1. Moreover, the next position is modified without considering the previous position.

Furthermore, as the results obtained by BPSO in solving different problems show the average cost function is improving at the first several iterations. It means that the algorithm is getting close to the optimal solution but the particles diverge from the optimal solution as time lapses, hence the algorithm does not converge well. Therefore, an improved BPSO should cover the disadvantages of PSO and BPSO.

div.head: NBPSO framework
div.p: NBPSO was introduced by Rostami-Shahrbabak and Nezamabadi-pour [60,71] to address the disadvantages of BPSO. The algorithm uses (5) to update the next velocity and the velocity is transferred into a probability function in the interval [0, 1].
The next position of the ith particle is computed as follows:
div.formula: S v d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á ¼ 2 Â 1 1 þ e Àv d i ðtþ1Þ À 0:5 ;ð9Þ
if rand < Sðv d i ðt þ 1ÞÞ then x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ exchange x d i ðtÞ À Á else x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ x d i ðtÞ:ð10Þ
Similar to BPSO, v d i ðt þ1Þ
div.p: < v max and v max = 6.

div.head: BGSA framework
div.p: GSA is a meta-heuristic algorithm based on Newton's laws of gravity and motion. According to the gravity law, objects attract each other by gravitational force [33,73]. This force depends directly on the product of both objects' masses and is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

In GSA, the objects of the real world are considered as agents. Agents are a collection of masses that interact with each other based on Newton's laws. A heavier mass is a more efficient agent. Each mass (agent) presents a solution in the search space. As time lapses, masses are attracted by the heaviest mass, which has a better solution.
This system can be defined as N agents based on the law in n-dimensional search space. Therefore, the position of the ith agent is shown as follows:
div.formula: X ! i ¼ x 1 i ; x 2 i ; . . . ; x d i ; . . . ; x n i À Á ; for i ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; N:ð11Þ
div.p: The force of gravity from mass j on mass i at a specific time t is computed as (12) and the mass is represented as ( 13) and ( 14):
div.formula: F d ijðtÞ
GðtÞ ¼ GðG 0 ; tÞ:ð16Þ
div.p: Also, the total force acting on the agent i at time t in dimension d is computed as follows:
div.formula: F d i ðtÞ ¼ X N j2Kbest; j-i rand j Â F d ij ðtÞ;ð17Þ
div.p: where Kbest is the set of the first K agents with the best fitness value and the biggest mass. At the start, Kbest is initialized at K 0 and linearly reduced step-by-step as time lapses.
The force accelerates the agent i based on the law of motion as follows:
div.formula: a d i ðtÞ ¼ F d iðtÞ
M d i ðtÞ :ð18Þ
div.p: This acceleration moves the agent from one position to another. The next velocity and position of agent i in dimension d are computed as follows:
div.formula: v d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ v d i ðtÞ þ rand i Â a d i ðtÞ:ð19Þ
x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ x d i ðtÞ þ v d i ðt þ 1Þ:ð20Þ
div.p: In the binary GSA (BGSA), the force, acceleration and velocity are updated based on ( 12)- (19). The R ij (t) in ( 15) is computed as the Hamming distance between two agents, i and j, and G is a linear decreasing function as follows:
div.formula: GðtÞ ¼ G 0 1 À t T ;ð21Þ
div.p: where G 0 is a constant, t is the current iteration and T is the total number of iterations.

In the binary search space, the agent's position is switched between '0' and '1'. Therefore, a probability function is defined to map the value of velocity in the interval [0, 1]. That is, BGSA modifies the velocity according to (19) and the new position changes to either '0' or '1' based on the probability of the function as follows: < v max and v max = 6. Since, the BGSA may trap in local optima when solving high dimensional optimization problems, an improved BGSA (IBGSA) [68] has been proposed by enhancing the transfer function. The IBGSA has got the ability to overcome the stagnation situation. This allows that the search algorithm explores a larger group of possibilities and avoids stagnation.
div.formula: S v d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á ¼ tanh v d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á ;ð22Þ
if rand < S v d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á then x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ complementðx d i ðtÞÞ else x d i ðt þ

div.head: BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI -the proposed methods
div.p: MC is an area of computational intelligence inspired by Darwinian principles of natural evolution and Dawkins' concept of cultural evolution. MC uses complex structures such as the combination of simple agents and memes to solve problems [34,57,58]. MA as a class of optimization algorithm is one of the applications of MC in problem-solving. According to the definition in [31], MA is an optimization algorithm composed of an evolutionary framework and a list of local search algorithms activated within the generation cycle of the external framework.

MC uses the notion of meme(s) as units of information encoded in computational representations for the purpose of problem-solving [20]. It covers a plethora of potentially rich meme-inspired computing methodologies, frameworks and operational algorithms including simple hybrids, adaptive hybrids and memetic automaton. Hybridization is one important feature evident in the field of MC. Also, adaptation of parameters and operators is one of the most important and promising areas of research in MC [46,63]. They are used to speed up the convergence rate and solution accuracy of algorithms. A classification of adaptive MAs was proposed by Ong et al. [63]. By updating and revisiting this classification, the coordination of the memes can be summarized as the following categories [57]:

1. Adaptive hyper-heuristic: the hyper-heuristic acts as an upper-level algorithm to control several low-level heuristics for finding a near-optimal solution [45]. The memes are coordinated by means of a prefixed scheme or schedule. The memes can be activated randomly or deterministically. The deterministic schemes can be implemented using a simple schedule for each meme.

2. Meta-Lamarckian learning: it is the use of multiple local search methods during a MA search in the spirit of Lamarckian learning [62]. Local search methods have different biases and these make a method efficient for some problems. Therefore, applying multiple local search methods and meta-Lamarckian learning in MA searches improve the search performance and reduce the probability of using an inappropriate local method.
3. Self-adaptive and co-evolutionary: This is relies on the evolutionary principles for the meme development and selection.
Therefore, the most promising operators is selected by participating memes in evolution, undergo recombination and selection operators.
4. Fitness diversity-adaptive: a measure of the diversity is applied to select and to activate the most proper memes.

MC structures are composed of heterogeneous operators. Caraffini et al. [12] proposed a simple structure parallel memetic structure (PMS) for solving optimization problems. PMS is a single solution optimization algorithm composed of tree operators: a stochastic global search and two local search algorithms. The stochastic global search explores the whole search space for finding promising regions. The first local search explores the space along the axes, and the second carries out diagonal movements in the direction of the estimated gradient. Also, Caraffini et al. [13] introduced a separability prototype for automatic memes (SPAM). It is a computational prototype for automatic design of optimization algorithms. A meta-heuristic algorithm will be successful on a given optimization problem if it can provide a balance between the exploration (diversification) and the exploitation (intensification). Exploitation is needed to identify parts of the search space with high quality solutions.
Exploitation is important to intensify the search in some promising areas of the accumulated search experience [10].

To enhance the performance of BPSO, both PSO and BPSO should be improved. In following section, HTPSO is introduced and in the next sections, BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI are proposed to solve the optimizations problems in the binary search spaces.

div.head: HTPSO framework
div.p: HTPSO tends to overcome the disadvantages of PSO by avoiding local optima and accelerating the convergence rate.

PSO has shown a better performance than LPSO in unimodal problems and LPSO has presented good results in multimodal ones [5,7,8]. Hence, both local and global topologies are hybridized in HTPSO to improve the exploration and exploitation abilities.
In HTPSO algorithm, each particle uses the best position found by its neighbors ðP lbest ! Þ to update the particle's velocity as follows:
div.formula: P lbest i ! ¼ p 1 lbest i ; p 2 lbest i ; . . . ; p d lbest i ; . . . ; p n lbest i :ð24Þ
v d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ wðtÞ Â v d i ðtÞ þ C 1 ðtÞ Â rand 1 Â p d best i ðtÞ À x d i ðtÞ þ C 2ðtÞ
x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ x d i ðtÞ þ v d i ðt þ 1Þ þ C 3 ðtÞ Â rand 3 Â p d gbest ðtÞ À x d i ðtÞ :ð26Þ
div.p: In (25), w is inertia weight and is computed as:
div.formula: wðtÞ ¼ w max À t Â ðw max À w min Þ T ;ð28Þ
div.p: where t and T are the current iteration and the total number of iterations, respectively.
Also, C 1 (t), C 2 (t) and C 3 (t) are acceleration coefficients and modified according to (29):
div.formula: C j ðtÞ ¼ C jmin þ ðC jmax À C jmin Þ T Â t; j ¼ 1; 2; 3:ð29Þ
div.p: Similar to PSO, the second term in ( 25) is called the cognition term, and the third terms in ( 25) and ( 26) are named the social terms. In ( 26), x d i ðt þ 1Þ < x max and x max is set to a constant based on the search space bound.

As shown in Fig. . Therefore, the ability of exploration of new area and exploitation around the good solution will be increased by this way. At the beginning, the particles search new spaces; by lapse of iterations, the exploration fades out and the exploitation fades in so that the particles accelerate to the best solution.

div.head: BHTPSO framework
div.p: In BHTPSO, the particle's velocity is calculated as (25). For the particle's position, the following concepts should be considered: A large absolute value of velocity must provide a high probability of changing particle's position with respect to its previous position (from '0' to '1' or vice versa). A small absolute value of the velocity must provide a small probability of changing the position. In other words, a zero value of the velocity represents that the particle position is good and must not be changed. Hence, a proper probability function (as shown in Fig. 3) can be considered as follows:
div.formula: SðaÞ ¼ jtanhðaÞj:ð30Þ
div.p: In BHTPSO, if the best position found by particles is not changed in several sequential iterations, a small value is added to (30) to accelerate the convergence rate and to escape from a local optimum. This value is defined as follows:
div.formula: E ¼ erf NF T 0 ¼ 2 ffiffiffi ffi p p Z NF T 0 0 e Àt 2 dt;ð31Þ
div.p: where erf is error function (also called the Gauss error function). NF is the number of times that the best position has not changed in the sequential iterations. T 0 is a time constant selected based on the problem. Therefore, the next position of each particle is computed as follows:
div.formula: a d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ v d i ðt þ 1Þ þ C 3 ðtÞ Â rand 3 Â p d gbest ðtÞ À x d i ðtÞ ;ð32Þ
S a d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á ¼ E þ ð1 À EÞ Â tanh a d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á ;ð33Þ
if rand 4 < S a d i ðt þ 1Þ À Á then x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ complement x d i ðtÞ À Á else x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ x d i ðtÞ; for i ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; N:ð34Þ
In (32), a d i ðt þ1Þ
div.p: < a max and a max is set to a constant based on the search space bound.

div.head: BHTPSO-QI -A variant of BHTPSO
div.p: The BHTPSO algorithm is incorporated with a quadratic crossover operator to form the BHTPSO-QI algorithm. The general structure of the BHTPSO-QI algorithm is shown in Fig. 4. BHTPSO-QI computes the new position of particle ẽ X according to (35):
div.formula: ẽ X ¼ X ! j xor X ! k or

div.head: Experimental results
div.p: The proposed BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI algorithms are compared with some well-known BPSO algorithms and BGSA. They are tested on various nonlinear functions [22,51,76,85] and the 0-1 MKP benchmarks [4] to evaluate their performances.

div.head: Nonlinear functions
div.p: In this section, several types of nonlinear functions including unimodal, multimodal, rotated, shifted, shifted and rotated, hybrid, and composition functions are applied to assess the efficiency of proposed methods.

In unimodal functions, the convergence rate of algorithm is more interesting than the final results because other methods have been designed to optimize these functions. In multimodal functions, finding an optimal (or a good near-global optimal) solution is important. These functions are more difficult to optimize because the number of local optima exponentially increases as the dimension increases. Therefore, the search algorithms should not become trapped in a local optimum and should be able to obtain the best solutions.

In rotated functions, the rotation increases the complexity of function but does not impact the shape of the function. For these functions, an orthogonal matrix M is generated and the vector X In hybrid functions, the variables are randomly divided into some sub-components and different basic functions are applied in the sub-components. Composition functions merge the properties of the sub-functions and are made of some basic functions [51].
In the experiment, thirty (30) minimization functions (F 1 À F 30 ) and one maximization function (F 31 ) are applied as detailed in Table 1. All functions are shown as follows:
(F 1 ) Sphere Model (Unimodal Function)

À exp 1 n X n i¼1 cos 2px i ! þ 20 þ e 439 439 440 (F 10 ) Generalized Penalized Function (Multimodal Function) 441 F 10 ðxÞ ¼ p n 10 sinðpy 1 Þ þ X nÀ1 i¼1 ðy i À 1Þ 2 ½1 þ 10 sin 2 ðpy iþ1 Þ þ ðy n À 1Þ 2 ( ) þ X n i¼1
y i ¼ 1 þ x i

À exp 1 n X n i¼1 cos 2pz i ! þ 20 þ e þ fbias 19 ; fbias 19 ¼ À140; z ¼ x À o (F 20 ) Shifted Generalized Griewank Function (Multimodal Function) F 20 ðxÞ ¼ 1 4000 X n i¼1 z 2 i À Y n i¼1 cos z i ffi ffi i p þ 1 þ fbias 20 ; fbias 20 ¼ À180; z ¼ x À o (F 21 ) Shifted Rastrign Function (Multimodal Function) F 21 ðxÞ ¼ X n i¼1 z 2 i À 10 cosð2pz i Þ þ 10 Â Ã þ fbias 21 ; fbias 21 ¼ À330; z ¼ x À o (F 22 )
div.p: Shifted and Rotated Rosenbrock's Function (Multimodal Function) F 24 ðzÞ ¼ f 24 ðzÞ þ fbias 24 ; fbias 24 ¼ 1000; z ¼ M 1000ðx À oÞ 100 The algorithms are evaluated based on low and high dimensions. Firstly, BPSO, BLPSO, NBPSO and BGSA are selected to compare their results with BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI on benchmark functions F 1 À F 21 . The n = 8, and bit_num = 15 are considered for the benchmarks, therefore, dim is equal to 120. Secondly, the dim will be increased and the performance of BPSO, BLPSO, NBPSO, INBPSO (global topology), INBPSOL (local topology), MBPSO, and BGSA are compared with the proposed methods. Some of benchmarks F 1 À F 21 , and difficult functions (F 22 À F 30 ) are applied in the evaluation as detailed in Table 1. The parameters of algorithms are listed in Table 2 as used in their references, and the number of neighbors is set to 3 for local topology.

f 24 ðxÞ ¼ 418:9829 Â n À X n i¼1 gðz i Þ; z i ¼ x i þ 4:209687462275036e þ 02 gðz i Þ ¼ z i sinðjz i j 1 2 if jz i j 6 500ð500

F 25 ðzÞ ¼ f 25 ðzÞ þ fbias 25 ; fbias 25 ¼ 1500; z ¼ M 5ðx À oÞ 100 þ 1 f 25 ðxÞ ¼ f 0 25 f 00 25 ðx 1 ; x 2 Þ À Á þ f 0 25 f 00 25 ðx 2 ; x 3 Þ À Á þ . . . þ f 0 25 f 00 25 ðx nÀ1 ; x n Þ À Á þ f 0 25 f 00 25 ðx n ; x 1 Þ À Á f 0 25 ðxÞ ¼ 1 4000 X D i¼1 x 2 i À Y D i¼1 cos x i ffi ffi i p þ 1 f 00 25 ðxÞ ¼ X DÀ1 i¼1 100 x 2 i À x iþ1 À Á 2 þ ðx i À
f 26 ðxÞ ¼ gðx 1 ; x 2 Þ þ gðx 2 ; x 3 Þ þ . . . þ gðx nÀ1 ; x n Þ þ gðx n ; x 1 Þ (F 27 )

div.head: Results and discussion of nonlinear benchmark functions for the low dimension
div.p: Six algorithms of BHTPSO, BHTPSO-QI, BPSO, BLPSO, NBPSO and BGSA, are randomly initialized and run independently 30 times on the benchmark functions F 1 À F 21 with dim = 120. The total number of iterations is set to 500, N = 50 (Population size) and T 0 = 800 (Time constant in ( 31)). The average best solution, the standard deviation (SD) and the median of the best solution in the last iteration are reported in Tables 3 and4. The best results from among the algorithms are shown in bold numbers. In these tables, the algorithms are ranked based on the average best results. Moreover, the Wilcoxon's rank sum test [83] is conducted in order to determine whether the results obtained by the BHT-PSO and the BHTPSO-QI algorithms are different from those generated by other algorithms with a statistical significance. The test returns p-value, h-value, and zval (the value of the z-statistic computed for large samples), where the confidence level is fixed at 0.95. These tests are shown in Tables 5 and6, where h-value = 1 indicates the proposed algorithm significantly outperformed the compared algorithm with 95% certainty, h-value = À1 represents that the compared algorithm is significantly better than the proposed algorithm, and h-value = 0 denotes that the results of the two considered algorithms are not significantly different. In these tables, rows 1 (Better), 0 (Same), and À1 (Worse) give the number of functions that the BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI perform significantly better than, almost the same as, and significantly worse than the compared algorithm, respectively.

The experimental results show that BHTPSO-QI performs superior results for most of the mentioned functions. The best and the second best algorithms in the all tables are BHTPSO-QI and BHTPSO, respectively.

As shown in Tables 3 and4, the BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI algorithms surpass the BPSO, BLPSO, NBPSO and BGSA algorithms in minimizing functions 1-11, 13, 14, 16, 17, 18 and 21. According to the Wilcoxon's rank sum test in Tables 5 and6, the results of the BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI algorithms are statistically significantly different from the four compared algorithms.

The results obtained by algorithms for F 5 (as unimodal function), and F 10 (as multimodal function) are shown in Fig. 5(a) and (b), respectively. In Fig. 6(a) and (b), the performance of algorithms for F 14 (as rotated function) and F 18 (as shifted function) is shown, respectively. The superior convergence rate of BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI are observed from these figures. The results in the figures indicate that BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI tend to find the global optimum faster than BPSO, BLPSO, NBPSO, and BGSA algorithms and achieve the highest accuracy from among all the algorithms.

div.head: Results and discussion of nonlinear benchmark functions for high dimension
div.p: In this section, the performance of BHTPSO, BHTPSO-QI, BPSO, BLPSO, NBPSO, INBPSO (global topology), INBPSOL (local topology), MBPSO, and BGSA algorithms are compared to find the best solution for the benchmark functions. The results are averaged over 30 runs and the average best solution, SD, median best solution, results of Wilcoxon's rank sum test, and algorithm rank for the minimization results are presented in Table 7. Several unimodal and multimodal functions are selected from among the functions F 1 À F 21 . In these functions, n = 14, bit_num = 30, and dim = 420 are considered. For functions F 22 À F 30 , n = 10, bit_num = 30, and dim = 300are selected. The total number of iterations is set at 800, N = 50 (Population size) and T 0 = 500 (Time constant in ( 31)). As seen in Table 7, BHTPSO-QI and BHTPSO algorithms in most cases provide superior results and in all cases are comparable with the other algorithms. BHTPSO-QI outperforms the other algorithms by a large margin for functions 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 11, 13, 18, 22, 23, 25, 26, and 29, and has the first rank in the majority of functions.

Also, BHTPSO shows a superior performance for functions 9, 10, 27, and 30. Similarly, according to the Wilcoxon's rank sum test, the results of the BHTPSO-QI and BHTPSO algorithms are statistically significantly different from the compared algorithms in almost all functions. In F 24 , and F 28 , BGSA and INBPSOL represent the best results, respectively. From the convergence plots presented in Fig. 7(a), (b), it can be concluded that the BHTPSO-QI algorithm provides a higher convergence rate for F 3 and F 26 than the others.

In Table 8, all algorithms are run 30 times for F 31 with different dimensions (20, 30, 50 and 100). The total number of iterations is set at 500, N = 50 (Population size) and T 0 = 800 (Time constant in ( 31)). The results illustrate that BHTPSO, BHT-PSO-QI, INBPSOL, and BGSA provide the optimal solution for all cases. Fig. 8 shows the faster convergence rate of BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI than the other algorithms for F 31 with n = 100. Although BGSA achieves the optimum solution, it requires a long time to obtain it. BLPSO shows the worst results as the dimension increases. In other words, the algorithm cannot tune itself to obtain good results.

div.head: The 0-1 MKP
div.p: The second problem considered to evaluate the performance of proposed methods, is the 0-1 MKP in the class of strongly NP-hard problems [19,27]. The problem is extensively employed in various applications and many real problems formulated 2014), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ins.2014.12.016 as the 0-1 MKP, such as cargo loading [75], resource allocating [28], cutting stock [29], capital budgeting [19], pollution prevention and control [3], and knowledge and economics engineering [54].
The 0-1 MKP consists of m knapsacks with limited capacities and n objects (or items). Each object has a profit and weight.
The objective of the 0-1 MKP is to select a subset of objects including a maximum profit without exceeding the capacity of knapsacks. The problem is formulated [19] as follows:
div.formula: Maximize X n i¼1 p i x i Subject to X n i¼1 w ij x i 6 b j x i 2 f0; 1g; 1 6 i 6 n; 1 6 j 6 m;ð36Þ
div.p: where n and m are the number of objects and knapsacks, respectively. b j represents the maximum capacity of each knapsack.
p i and w i are the profit and weight of the ith object. x i is either '0' or '1' and shows whether the ith object has been put into the knapsack or not.

Several methods using exact and approximate algorithms have been introduced to solve the 0-1 MKP [56,67,75,77]. Exact algorithms have the computational complexity of factorial or exponential, therefore they take a long time to obtain the results [56]. Hence, many researches applied meta-heuristic algorithms [2,9,18,47,86] in this regard. To solve the 0-1 MKP using the meta-heuristic algorithms, the length of each candidate solution (particle or chromosome) is considered as the number of objects (n). Population is randomly initialized with '0' and '1' values. '1' or '0' shows the object has been selected or not. Among the population, some solutions are infeasible because their total weights are more than the knapsack capacities. Many algorithms have been introduced in order to improve these solutions [9,19,81]. Some of them changed the solutions and others decrease the probability of selecting the infeasible solutions. Penalty Function (PF) technique is among Since, the aim of this study is to compare the performance of meta-heuristic algorithms by generated individual solution, 617 PF technique is applied to solve the 0-1 MKP because the other methods modify the solutions. Therefore, it is possible that an 618 infeasible solution or a bad solution converts to a good solution [9]. The PF function used [9] is as follows: 619
div.formula: Penalty ¼ P n i¼1 p i x i Q þ Max j¼1::m P n i¼1 w ji x i À b j À Á ;ð37Þ
div.p: where Q is a positive value, n and m are the number of objects and knapsacks, respectively. The benchmarks have been selected from OR-Library [4] as given in Table 9. In the table, Best Known is the maximum profit obtained by the library; n and m represent the number of objects and knapsacks, respectively. The selected benchmarks are among the hard and very difficult benchmarks in the datasets. The meta-heuristic algorithms are run for the benchmarks of Table 9 and the results are averaged over 30 independent 629 run. In all cases, the population size is set to 100 (N = 100) and T 0 = 800 (Time constant in (31)). w in BPSO and BLPSO is set to 1 630 because these algorithms show a better performance with this value [9,44]. The total number of iterations is set at 3000.
Other parameters are considered as Table 2.

The best, mean and worst maximum profits obtained by the algorithms in the last iteration are reported in Tables 10 and633 11. To evaluate the performance of algorithms, the average errors of the best, and mean profit are computed in the tables as 634 follows: 635 where L is the number of benchmarks in each table, t i is the maximum profit of ith benchmark and y i shows the average result of ith benchmark obtained by the algorithms.
div.formula: AE ¼ 1 L X L i¼1 t i À y i t i Â 100;ð38Þ
div.p: As the results in Tables 10 and11 show, BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI perform the better results with less average errors than the other algorithms. In these tables, BHTPSO-QI has the minimum error for the average (mean) maximum profit. BPSO shows the worst results and its performance considerably decreases as the number of objects and knapsacks increase. Also, BLPSO cannot tune itself in the more difficult benchmarks and provides poor results in some cases.

The good results of BHTPSO and BHTPSO-QI could be concluded from Fig. 9(a) for the benchmarks mknapcb3-5.500-04 and from Fig. 9(b) for mknapcb6-10.500-01, respectively. As seen, BHTPSO-QI tends to find the maximum profit faster than the other algorithms. Although BGSA shows good performance, it takes long time to obtain the results. It is computed as follows:
div.formula: MAE ¼ 1 L X L i¼1 jt i À y i j:ð39Þ
div.p: The BHTPSO-QI and BHTPSO show the first and second lowest MAE, respectively. The highest one belongs to BPSO. This indicates that the proposed algorithms perform well in the binary search space.

The complexity of the proposed algorithms is similar to the standard BPSO (local topology). However, the new algorithms have faster convergence rate than the compared algorithms as shown in Figs. 56789.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this study, BHTPSO algorithm has been introduced to extend the binary search capability and to improve convergent efficiency. Also, BHTPSO-QI algorithm has been proposed incorporating the quadratic crossover operator into the BHTPSO algorithm. Two set of problems in the binary search spaces have been considered to evaluate the performance of algorithms: The proposed algorithms have significantly lower error than the others. Additionally, the BHTPSO-QI algorithm is universally better than the BHTPSO algorithm. This indicates that the proposed BHTPSO method could be incorporated with the other algorithms to improve their performance even further.
